notesStmt.note: This manuscript was likely composed in April 1863. Whitman's own hand suggests an April 7, 1863 date for the composition of the manuscript, the date of Whitman's hospital visits, or both.

This manuscript was likely composed in May 1863, but it was almost certainly composed after May 2, 1863. Noah S. Laing was severely wounded on May 2, 1863 at the battle of Chancellorsville. Laing was later discharged for disability on August 24, 1864 at Grant General Hospital in Willets Point, New York ("6th New York Independent Battery, Light Artillery," Rosters of the NY Artillery Regiments During the Civil War, New York State Military Museum and Veterans Research Center Online).

div2.ab: I saw a seven or eight of the 14th Brooklyn going home on furlough—
div2.add: (*and very much ashamed & mad about it afterward)
div2.ab: a pretty bad case will get 60, 50, or 40 days—others 30, and so on
Joseph Armstrong, quiet Pennsylvania boy, very low with dysentery—I write this sitting by his bed—both of us crying—tells me, sobbing, he can’t help thinking of the time when his mother died
Joseph Armstrong, co H. 57th Penn. —(has sisters & brother young brother at home)

—a very bad case of dysentery, has been growing worse several days,—poor young fellow, as I see him lying there panting, the sweat in drops on his face, it seems hard enough—goes to my heart—he is a stout, lymphatic young man, very gentle and uncomplaining—was raised in North Rome, Bradford co. Pa.—was all through the Peninsular campaign—
—has been more or less ill in hospital, convalescent camp, &c for six months. His father & brother are both in the army.

div1.ab: is from Rahway, N.J. been out since June ‘61
has three brothers in the Army in the 30th N.J. Vol
worked for A. V. Shotwell large bakery Rahway, N.J.
there are fourfive brothers & threefour of them are in the war
was at Ball’s Bluff Williamsburgh Fair Oaks, Malvern Hill, & Chancellorsville
div1.note: Nearest friend A. V. Shotwell, Rahway, mother Margaret C Laing Care of R A Drake Plainfield N.J.
